snippet.textDisplay:
I can't express how much I prefer DS3 over ER.

There's just no comparison. Both games are good and have great high points..... but DS3 is just there to be enjoyed as is, while ER is bogged down with bloat and padding. I don't want to get lost for half an hour to find something interesting (or god forbid the 5th recolor of the same dungeon or boss), I want to actually do something interesting when I'm playing. I can do chores in rl.

snippet.textDisplay: I will say, as someone who played elden ring as their first souls game there is nothing like your first playthrough. Opening the doors from the starting area and seeing the massive world in front of you was incredible. Buying the game when it first came out, nobody had any guides or anything. It was just raw exploration. The feeling i got when i discovered a catacomb hidden in the side of some random mountain. Oh man. And Margits cutscene. Such a good way to introduce players to what they're dealing with. Is dark souls 3 worth playing still? Probably. I would wager most of the souls-games are. But i stand by the opinion that Elden Ring should be every new players's first. The cutscenes evoke power in the enemies, and the fights are super cinimatic. Every single cutscene had me grinning ear-to-ear and every single fight had me equally panicked and in awe lol. No spoilers, but when you reach the final boss fight, it FEELS like a final boss fight. That cutscene when you enter immediately makes you realize what you're in for. As of now, Elden ring has become my favorite game of all time.

snippet.textDisplay:
In terms of world building and oh shit moments, Elden Ring is amazing. I had first played Dark Souls 2 and loved how hard and unbelievably esoteric it seemed. So encounter ER next was like going to warp speed. I went to NG 4 before getting the DLC. However the criticisms from this video are spot on, it does get a bit repetitive and you have to respec or choose new builds to make it fun again. 

However in terms of pure joyful playthrough Bloodborne and Sekiro are unmatched. 

I keep dreaming that Sekiro will birth a sequel with an open world ER style with the unique fight mechanics of the original. Sekiro allows for multiple play through just enjoying the rhythm of the battles every time like playing your favorite songs on an instrument. 

Going to have to play DS3 and see how the comparison goes ðŸ˜Š

snippet.textDisplay:
You should absolutely go back and play DS3 if ER was your first From Soft experience, go back and play every Souls game in their catalog if you can. 

My first forays into From Soft were BB and DS3, falling in love with those just made me wanna go back through the prior games to not only experience the evolution of the genre but also to get a different experience that was still in the same vein as what I liked in those other games.

This is especially true in the case of DS3, as anyone who has played both it and ER will be able to recognize how DS3 is basically â€œER-lite,â€ the template for ER  if you will.

snippet.textDisplay: Elden Ring spoiled me so much that I can't play most games for more than a few hours because there's always something missing. Elden Ring is like a Wagner opera with bombastic, serene, joyful and tearful moments, all of them exceptionally beautiful and with a dynamic range hardly ever seen before. Almost every other game is like modern music: constant. DS3 is like that. Areas do vary to some degree but most of them are a bit better or a bit worse than "meh". Sure, Anor Londo is quite a looker but compared to Leyndell it's more like an AI generated scene rather than a work of art or a place where people could have lived. Weapon and spell variety is nowhere near as good as in Elden Ring. Lorewise the games couldn't be further apart as well.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who played ER before Dark souls 3 i must say it was a leap up in quality.
-1. The enemies and bosses feel like they are playing the same game as you, what i mean by this is that in Elden ring has dark souls movement with the enemies moving as fast as the ones in Sekiro.
-2. while it brought nothing new to the table it perfected what it already had.
-3. The game does not get worse as it goes on like Elden ring, but it gets even better.
-4. Ds3 has a lot more replay value, though i think thats because Elden ring is open world and Ds3 is linear, i recently tried to start a third playthrough of Elden ring and it is such a slog to Re-explore. meanwhile i started a third playthrough of Ds3 and it is almost as fun as the first.
This is all my subjective opinion so please dont hurt me, Oh please dont.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls III deserves a lot of praise for the way it teaches you the mechanics. It does so gradually and naturally.

You get the basics of combat with the Hollows at the Cemetery of Ash. The bossfight with Iudex Gundyr shows you a phase transition and telegraphed attacks, some of which are delayed to punish panic rolls.
The High Wall of Lothric introduces the large Hollows with bigger health pools that you cannot simply R1 spam in one go. This teaches you to manage your Stamina and exploit their slow attacks for backstabs. The ones with halberds also have the push move that can break your guard. There is your first Mimic, a locked door and a key that you must find, exploding powder kegs, and a shortcut back to a Bonfire. Vordt introduces the Frostbite status effect.
The Undead Settlement is next, expanding upon the concept of multiple ways through the level. It introduces the Dark Spirit invasion in the form of an NPC, your first elevator with two platforms, and the area boss that must be fought without lock-on in order to target the vulnerable blisters. And so on.

I know that the game has been criticized for being too linear, but that allowed it to really fine-tune its learning curve. Since you can mostly only progress in one direction, it was possible to tailor everything in such a way that it really teaches the player the mechanics one after another, without punishing you for something you couldn't possibly have known beforehand. This means that your defeats don't feel unfair and your victories don't feel unearned; you have been given all the tools you needed to make it.

snippet.textDisplay: Ds3 was my first from game so Iâ€™m definitely biased but after 2 full play throughs of Elden ring + the Expansion Iâ€™d say Ds3 is better overall. Honestly I think I like Sekiro and Bloodborne more at this point as well. Nearly every â€œdifficultâ€ boss in Elden Ring is designed around the use of summons. They are totally beatable without them, for sure, and just to iterate where Iâ€™m coming from, I have soloed all of them. But my god are they just frustrating and Iâ€™m usually not even excited after defeating them. Over half of the time I felt like my â€œvictoryâ€ was more down to RNG than anything else. This is the polar opposite to my experience in Sekiro and Ds3 in particular. Maybe I just havenâ€™t played these games in a while so Iâ€™m thinking about playing Ds3 again just to see.

snippet.textDisplay: As good as ER is, at times I feel it's too big for it's own good. While open world lovers love it, I'd rather  the development time spent on all the empty space between legacy dungeons, the lackluster tombs and boring caves was spent to create smaller but much more detailed and intricate levels. Imagine the twists and turns of Yharnam and DLC areas of DS2/DS3/BB but just a bit bigger given the longer dev cycle. Now that'd be awesome. My favourite areas (by level design and geometry I mean) are all the legacy dungeons - Leyndell, Stormveil and Elphael are amazing (but Elphael enemy scaling is wacked)

snippet.textDisplay: Is Dark Souls 3 worth your time? Honestly the bosses alone are sort of worth it... I think Sister Friede, and Midir are still my all time favorite bosses from From Software. I know there's ton of other great bosses in the whole series, but those two really stuck out to me for different reasons. Friede for the sheer shock and awe of the third phase, coupled with just how insanely aggressive, variable, and fun her third phase moveset is. And Midir because it's just so satisfying to do the fight correctly (by staying in front of him and baiting his melee attacks). Midir is really cool because the correct strategy makes you fight this bad ass Abyss devouring Arch Dragon head on, coupled with the fact that I still think it's the best Dragon fight they've ever made (Palcidusax being a pretty close second though).

Friede for the sheer shock and awe of the third phase, coupled with just how insanely aggressive, variable, and fun her third phase moveset is. And Midir because it's just so satisfying to do the fight correctly (by staying in front of him and baiting his melee attacks). Midir is really cool because the correct strategy makes you fight this bad ass Abyss devouring Arch Dragon head on, coupled with the fact that I still think it's the best Dragon fight they've ever made (Palcidusax being a pretty close second though).

snippet.textDisplay: Bloodborne Sekiro and DS3 are all modern like Elden Ring, Iâ€™d say the combat in Sekiro is even better than Elden Ring. The thing with Elden Ring is, as a person who plays these games for the bosses, I only started to enjoy Elden Ring towards the end where you start fighting loads of the Demi-Gods back to back like Godfrey, Malenia, Maliketh and Radagon. Thing is with Dark Souls 3, with AND without the dlc it is more concentrated with amazing bosses that are at the level of the Elden Ring demigods, the game is smaller yet there are more good bosses in Dark Souls 3 than Elden Ring. To name a few youâ€™ve got Dancer, Pontiff, Nameless King and Soul of Cinder and many more especially with the DLCs. To this day after just having finished Elden Ring and loving the bosses at the end, Iâ€™d say itâ€™s definitely my least favourite at least boss-wise out of the 4 games Iâ€™ve mentioned. Youâ€™d have a blast playing any of the other 3 games they feel just as modern as Elden Ring (what I mean by modern is itâ€™s easy to get used to after playing Elden Ring whereas older games like ds1 and ds2 feel a lot lessâ€¦ fun? Take a lot longer to get used to? Make u FEEL like youâ€™ve gone 2 console generations back? Whereas the other 3 games feel timeless)

snippet.textDisplay:
Played them all in order they were released. My opinion. 
From a Lore perspective: Demons Souls is king. Because it received no DLC or sequel, it has so much that can be explored. 
As far as gameplay I do think Elden Ring is king as it avoids a lot of the inconsistency the other games had particularly with PVP. 
DS2 is the worst. 
DS1 if you want to taste the original Dark Souls with its limited robotic gameplay. 

DS3 is basically a baby Elden Ring with Demons Souls level design.

I think elden ring has chunks of its structure that are objectively the best content FromSoft has ever made, BUT there are clearly also chunks of the game that are some of the laziest and most unrepentantly bad design choices in their entire library kf games.

people who shit on DS2, for example, as a gank fest but then say elden ring is a masterpiece are delusional. DS3 might have the best design of the dark souls trilogy, but lacks the grandeur of some of the art design from Elden ring. But DS3 doesnt overstay its welcome compared to ER as well.

I feel like the idea of an open world is instantly seen as a positive...  When Elden Ring came out, Dark Souls 3 was my fav FromSoft game...  And after giving Elden Ring a try, Dark Souls 3 is still my fav FromSoft game...  

My main take away is that more "linear" game design always for Miyazaki to play with your emotions at a better rate, where as "open world" it's a lot more difficult...

Playing Elden Ring gave me the feeling of boredom, then feeling of I found something, to then be finished with that something pretty quickly and back to boredom...

All in all, Dark Souls 3 is great to experience after Elden Ring, I would not be surprised if some end up liking DS3 more...

snippet.textDisplay:
I still canâ€™t decide which game I like better. I do think you nailed it though, Elden Ring is way more fun in the beginning as youâ€™re messing around and establishing your character, but then I often find myself aimless on subsequent playthroughs. I quite like the linearity of DS3. Nice to just focus directly on the challenge ahead. Also DS3 bosses are just unmatched for me. Dancer, Pontiff, Twin Princes, Midir, & Lady Friede are all engrained in my memory. For their substantial challenge and their overall visual design, lore, and soundtracks. And so many others are great too. Elden Ring has some excellent bosses as well, I just find DS3 has more memorable ones. 

Pros and cons to both and Iâ€™m happy we have both games for different moods/types of players, but I agree one is not necessarily â€œbetterâ€ than the other. Theyâ€™re both masterpieces.

snippet.textDisplay: I enjoy all of FromSofts titles. But the two I find myself returning to over and over are Sekiro and Bloodborne. A few days ago, I picked up Lies of P. If you are a SekiroBorne fan too, I canâ€™t stress enough how much you will LOVE Lies of P. Itâ€™s a perfect combo of the two, with just enough original gameplay ideas to make it feel like the evolution I hoped Elden Ring would be. It proves that all of the unique elements of each FromSoft title can totally be combined without damaging the gameplay. To top it off, the art style is also spectacular. FromSofts beautiful worlds are a big part of what drives me to keep moving forward. And Lies of P nails that concept. Itâ€™s kind of like a SteamPunk clockwork Bloodborne kind of thing. The Pinocchio theme is only a minimal template to create a skeleton for the world. It does all sorts of interesting stuff with the theme.

As someone who started with elden ring and decided to go back and play the entire DS trilogy even though Iâ€™m only 3 hours into DS3, DS1 was a masterpiece in atmosphere, customization, fresh boss designs, and world building. DS2 although itâ€™s ambitious and albeit risky execution I would say itâ€™s art style and use of color made the world entirely more vibrant, the level of bloating in enemies letâ€™s the difficulty overshadow the best aspects of the game and itâ€™s innovative mechanics ex. Human effigies, lifegems, etc. personally I think I prefer the armor sets over DS1 (honestly overheated in my opinion)
DS3 seems like an amalgamation of fromsofts innovations throughout the years, atmosphere, level design, build depth, art style, and most importantly lore depth. 
I will say this, I feel like Iâ€™ve been living under a rock for the past decade missing out on these games during release, I already have demons souls and bloodborne downloaded on my ps5 thanks to ps plus, Iâ€™ll probably play the ever loving fuck out of them and enjoy them just as much, the only one Iâ€™m dreading is sekiro!

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls 3 is by FAR the most overrated FROM game ever. It's absolutely fantastic IF you've never played EITHER Elden Ring OR ANY OF THE PREVIOUS Souls games, including Demons. 

IF you have, however, you'll realize what this game is - a highly polished, super-appealing-to-newcomers well-made game that is nevertheless such a shameless ripoff and mishmash of old games and ideas that any self-respecting developer should kinda be ashamed of it, honestly. 

Again, fantastic game on its own merits in its own bubble - the most polished Dark Souls, great combat, great DLC, great music, plenty to like. But the more previous DS games you play the more you'll get annoyed at just how lazily it straight up rips off content from every one of them and calls it a day. And I'm not talking just the callback to certain enemies or Anor Londo - it has entirely way too much shit that is just a straight up ripoff, even for something that's part of a trilogy, and that's without even getting into everything it cribs from Demons, such as the Asylum area.

snippet.textDisplay: I actually just finished DS3 recently after Elden Ring. I completed it only once back in the day, because I wasn't a fan of it. That opinion is still the same. I played ds1 on released, demon's souls yadda yadda. DS3 is my least favorite souls game. For every good game decision, they make 2 bad ones. It was too much bloodborne style combat (Enemy atk spam, flailing about, fast pace.) with having mismatched character tools that don't match enemies. They do not follow the same rules as you. Elden Ring fixed most of the issues with that imo. DS3 has no poise, build variety, weapon selection etc. Most weapons are weak, Faith/STR is the only real build thats worth it in the game. Though, DS1 had the issue too in some cases.

snippet.textDisplay: I would not really put it that way. Elden Ring can be one of the hardest in the franchise if you want. The key is if you want, if you play it with summons and magic and stack a certain stat, it can become almost trivial. Dark souls is more of a journey were it suddenly clicks, you die over and over and your brain subconsciously picks up on these timings it's not that the game gets easier rather the opposite it is that you improve as a player drastically from were you started and you do not recognize or even notice this through your first playthrough. Elden Ring has some of the toughest bosses with very inventive mechanics were they introduce the jump feature to actually dodge animations. I expect FromSoftware to use this feature even more going forward. If you want to watch what I consider art have a look at ONGBAL on YT playing these games. Before I saw him I never knew I was a newbie.

snippet.textDisplay:
i've beaten elden 4x now, each different builds, and each thru all optional areas/major bosses.  i've beaten ds3 upwards of 15x.  certainly worth it, the best of the dark souls games by a wide margin imo (as in 1,2, and 3). also, the dlc is incredible, gael is at the tippy top of my 'best bosses ever created' list, mechanically, environmentally, musically, cinematically, contextually, just absolutely perfect. 

for anyone that couldn't make it past gundyr and loved elden, absolutely worth trying again.  while elden still takes the cake for me, there is definitely something to be said for the more linear pathway, the whole experience feels much more intentional and polished, granted it takes a hit in exploration and discovery for that (hard to beat that first play of elden and getting teleported to florida or first entering siofra well or leyndell). one thing is that ds3 is much 'darker' in aesthetic overall, which i take as a negative.  the contrast between the beauty and ugliness in elden gives the whole world a much more dynamic and fantastical feel overall.   ds3 however, has many of the best bosses.  i thought eldens bosses were much, much weaker in comparison, with really only morgott, godfrey, radagon (eldenbeast not so much), maliketh and mayyybe mohg getting close to the quality of many of ds3's bosses (i'm not a big fan of malenia, always seems to feel absolutely unfair or absolutely cheesed, with the difference often coming down to rng, makes it feel like an unsatisfying win the 4 times i've beaten her).   

i'm guessing most will split between the two based on whether they emphasize gameplay, or immersion/rpg/exploration elements. 

and of course, if good bosses is what you're after, neither game holds a candle to sekiro, atleast mechanically (not sure i could pick between isshin and gael).

snippet.textDisplay: I don't have time to watch the video right now, but I agree with most of the comments I've read so far. Elden Ring was my first soulslike game and even though I enjoyed it, I was a bit too confused at the beginning. I gave up on Elden Beast and couldn't get back to it. Then I played Sekiro which was considered a way harder game than Elden Ring, but to be honest, I loved it. Probably one of my best gaming expieriences. I finished it and felt like I won't have this much fun and challenge anymore. Recently I bought DS3 and I must admit that the intro is way better and less overwhelming than it was in Elden Ring. The game felt quite easy until Pontiff Shulyvahn, then it drastically increased the difficulty level (which is a bit confusing, but it's fine for me). Anyways, the world design, combat system and overall game experience is really good. I don't enjoy it as much as I did enjoy Sekiro, because the combat is more based on the rolling dodges than on parries and it just feels slower and less realistic (and fair?), but definitely it's worth a try after Elden Ring.

snippet.textDisplay:
I donâ€™t quite agree with not â€œgettingâ€œ a new souls game when playing it for the first time, at least not DS3 and ER, DS1 & DS2 are a different story all together when it comes to that aspect, where I would agree. After playing DS3 through hell and back, Elden Ring just felt very natural to me when I first played it. Since the movement and speed of the game felt basically the same, it was really only a matter of learning movesets from new enemy types, and exploiting movesets of those already known to me. 

Example. DS3 players will know exactly how the Imps in the dungeons will behave, and that theyâ€™ll cling to walls after fighting just one of them. Not because theyâ€™re absolute gaming gods that can do everything, but because theyâ€™ll recognize their moveset, which was already present for another enemy type in DS3, and was just reused for a new character model.

Example 2. Banished Knights (Sword and Shield variant) are basically Lothric Knights+ (with a couple tweaks). Only difference being the Storm Attacks they get (Lothric Knights had a stance weapon art instead), and them no longer being poise broken after every attack like in DS3.

snippet.textDisplay: so im going to state my gaming experience about Dark souls. If you didnt play the first one, I cant really recommend doing it. the 3rd one is a 10/10 and you should play it asap if you liked elden ring. DS2 is also good, albeit i think the bosses were easy af (save the burnt Ivory knight and FKnight). I wouldnt say DS3 is  any more difficult, but that game has a boss in it that puts melania to shame. Its one of the best fights ive ever played and while it took me months to kill him the first time, TNK will always be the one boss that makes that game the best in my opinion. DS1 I think has just aged to a point where I don't want to replay it anymore (It was fire on release though), and DS2 just never packed enough difficulty for me. Sekiro is amazing also but I dont like the combat system (I love my great swords what can i say). anyways thats my firmsoft review

snippet.textDisplay:
im not even gonna watch 1 min of this video before saying my opinion so keep that in mind reading this.
DS3 was my favorite souls game of all time when i was in highschool. its been years since then and i decided to play ds2 with my brother and it was great fun jolly co-operation. we played bloodborne and it was a little laggy but it was also really fun. we started playing ds3 and it just fell flat in terms of feel and how it ran. multiplayer gets pretty frame laggy and the weapons and combat fall short in comparison to bloodborne. we had a blast with ds2 and bloodborne. playing ds3 kinda either made us want to play an older souls title or bloodborne. we got elden ring and it just feels like the good parts in ds3 got amplified. the only reason in my opinion to play ds3 is the weapon arts and the magic. mayybe the boss fights but i think bloodborne has more fun fights. elden ring simply has better weapon arts and magic and boss fights. if i want a slower game with a focus on exploring the levels then ill play ds2 or 1. if i want to play a fast pase game with fun weapons and bosses ill play bloodborne. if I want a mix of fast pase combat and exploration ill play elden ring. ds3 doesnt really have a place in my heart anymore and that makes me sad. oh also ds3 has the worst intro level.. high wall of lothric is boring linear and theres nothing of importance to do there except grab an estus shard. after that its the undead settlement and that part sucks too. the game doesn't start getting good untill after the first few boss fights. dark souls 2 i can choose like 4 different paths at the start of the game and i can choose if i want to finish areas or come back later. that's not a luxury ds3 gives. its linear untill after the catacombs of carthus. then theres like 2 different places to go. every ds3 playthrough feels similar. bloodborne is the same with that but again bloodborne has better weapons and combat so it doesn't feel as bad. ds3 had no place anymore

snippet.textDisplay:
I started my Soulslike journey with Dark Souls, played it through twice and spent a lot of time in a certain woodland ganking up on blue invaders, logging about 600 hours until Dark Souls 2 came along. Dark Souls 2 was the first game for which I collected all achievements in my life on the Xbox360. I played about 300 hours of it until I bought an Xbox one and could no longer play it. Until the Scholar of the First Sin edition released. I played that game for years; over 2000 hours, up into NG+80 and got all achievements for it. I spent hours upon hours on the bridge in the Iron Keep enjoying fight clubs and many hours in the arena's. It is also the only game in which I really enjoyed playing as a blue spirit. I then moved from Xbox One to PS4 and bought the SotfS edition again. Got all achievements for it for a third time and played the PVP side of the game right until the release day of Dark Souls 3. Dark Souls 3 became my true love. There is no game I played more than DS3. I had over 5000 hours in it by the time I moved on from my PS4 to PC gaming. The online aspect of that game kept it alive for me for so long. Fight clubs and 6 man multiplayer madness in the area behind Pontyf will forever be some of my favourite gaming memories. I have also played Demon Souls Remake on PS5 for about 30 hours before giving up on it because the death runs were just to tedious for my taste. I am currently 780 hours into my Elden Ring journey, but because the PVP aspect of it is nowhere near as good as the experience was in DS2 and DS3 I don't think I will ever get to the 2000 or 5000 hour mark.

My favourite bosses in the trilogy are: DS1: Great Greywolf Sif (I have this guy tattooed on my arm) DS2: The Fume Knight. DS3: Twin Princes. The funny thing is that although I have Sif tattooed on my arm, the Twin Princes fight is the first boss fight I think about whenever I think about the best boss fight I have ever had. It is just so good and the score is magnificent. That fight on itself is worth buying the game for.

snippet.textDisplay: In single player you can play elden ring at 120+ fps in offline mode, for some reason DS1 and DS3 feel very slow and glitchy on a modern PC. I guess if you play on console this doesn't matter. But even then Elden ring is just every mechanic in previous games refined, the only argument people seem to make is that they don't like the bosses, and that's subjective, as objectively every boss is mechanically superior to any dark souls game, maybe with a few bosses being an exception. DS3 was amazing in 2016, it just has older design elements that were changed for a reason.

snippet.textDisplay:
For anyone who is reading this and is considering buying Dark Souls 3, or any other souls-like for that matter, go for it! 

While it may be frustrating not being able to skip a boss you keep dying to, as long as you stick with it you will eventually beat it. Your brain has its own cheat or superpower called pattern recognition, which means that you will slowly get the hang of the boss over several attempts. Taking breaks is also something I highly recommend and I can't count the number of times I've been stuck on a boss and then came back from a break and proceeded to kill the boss on my first or second try.
